intro: Syngonanthus obtusifolius, commonly known as the broadleaf mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of host trees. It has small, leathery leaves that are typically oval or elliptical in shape. The plant produces small white or pale green flowers, followed by fleshy, red berries that are consumed by birds. Its growth is slow, and it can live for many years, often forming dense clusters on its host. The plant's botanical features make it an important component of certain forest ecosystems.
